s.gd: AON LATHA, thàinig aonaran a dh’fhuireach do’n bhail’ againn, uill, cha b’ann buileach do’n bhaile ach pìos beag air a thaobh a-muigh aig ceann an rathaid, ann am fear de na bothain a dh’fhàg an RAF air an cùlaibh an déidh a’ chogaidh.
s.en: One day, a loner came to our town to stay, well, it was not exactly to the town but a bit outside at the end of the road, in one of the huts that the RAF left behind after the war.

s.gd: ’Se a’ chiad rud a chunna sinn, ceò ag éirigh ás an t-simileir.
s.en: The first thing that we saw was smoke rising from the chimney.

s.gd: Feumaidh mi innse dhuibh gur e maighstir-sgoile a bh’annam fhìn uaireigin ach tha mi nise fuireach ’nam aonar, an déidh dhomh mo dhreuchd a leigeil sìos, ann an tigh comhfhurtail le leas air a bhialaibh far am bi mi a’ cur mheasan.
s.en: I must tell you that I was a schoolmaster at one time but I now live on my own, after giving up my job, in a comfortable house with a garden in front where I grow fruit.

s.gd: Bidh mi caitheamh mo thìde a’ coimhead ’s a’ toirt an aire do na nithean a tha dol air adhart anns a’ bhaile.
s.en: I spend my time watching and attending to the things that are going on in the town.

s.gd: Aig amannan bidh mi faireachdainn aonaranach.
s.en: At times I feel lonely.

s.gd: Ach nach eil a h-uile duine faireachdainn sin eadhon nuair a tha iad pòsda?
s.en: But doesn’t everyone feel that even when they are married?

s.gd: An latha seo, thachair Dougie rium ’s thubhairt e rium gu robh aonaran air a thighinn do’n bhaile.
s.en: On this day, I encountered Dougie and he said to me that a loner had come to the town.

s.gd: ’Sann aig Dougie a tha an aon bhuth a th’anns a’ bhaile ’s bidh e reic phàipearan ’s trealaich de gach seòrsa.
s.en: It is Dougie that has the only store that is in the town and he sells papers and bits and pieces of all sorts.

s.gd: Tha bhùth aige dìreach coltach ris na bùitean eile a chì sibh air feadh na Gàidhealtachd ann am bailtean beaga.
s.en: His store is just like the other stores that you see all over the Highlands in little towns.

s.gd: “Thàinig e steach do’n bhùth,” ars esan, “’S bha gach nì aige sgrìobhte sìos air pìos pàipeir ’s cha do bhruidhinn e rium idir.
s.en: “He came into the store,” he said, “And he had everything written down on a piece of paper and he didn’t say anything at all to me.”

s.gd: ’Sann a bha mi smaoineachadh an toiseach gur ann balbh a bha e, ach cha b’ann idir, oir beagan an déidh sin chuala mi e bruidhinn ris fhéin.
s.en: I thought at first that he was deaf, but he wasn’t at all, because shortly after that I heard him talking to himself.

s.gd: Bha e ’g iarraidh lof is ìm is càis is nithean mar sin.
s.en: He wanted a loaf and butter and things like that.

s.gd: Ach cha robh e ’g iarraidh pàipear-naidheachd idir.
s.en: But he didn’t want any newspaper at all.

s.gd: Duine mór àrd le baiseagal, is aodann donn leis a’ ghréin.
s.en: A big tall man with a bicycle, and a face brown with the sun.

s.gd: Is crios de ròpa mu aodach a tha a’ coimhead car salach is dubh.
s.en: And a belt of rope around clothing that looks somewhat dirty and black.

s.gd: Chan eil feusag air idir.
s.en: He didn’t have any facial hair whatsoever.

s.gd: Sùilean uabhasach gorm ann.
s.en: He had terribly blue eyes.

s.gd: ’S cha dubhairt e smid.
s.en: And he didn’t say a thing.

s.gd: Chuir seo cais orm, tha thu a’ tuigsinn, ach cha dubhairt mi càil ris.
s.en: This irritated me, you understand, but I didn’t say a thing to him.

s.gd: Ma tha e airson a bhith sàmhach cha chuir sin dragh orm-sa.
s.en: If he wants to be silent that doesn’t concern me.

s.gd: Tigh na galla dha.
s.en: Sod him.

s.gd: Co-dhiùbh, chuir e an trealaich a cheannaich e ann am poca ’s chuir e am poca air a’ bhaiseagal ’s a-mach leis chun a’ bhothain.
s.en: Anyway, he he put the bits and pieces that he bought in a bag and he put the bag on the bicycle and out with him to the hut.

s.gd: Tha fhios agad càit a bheil am bothan?”
s.en: You know where the hut is?”

s.gd: Thubhairt mi ris gu robh.
s.en: I said to him that I did.

s.gd: “’S tha e fuireach an siud ’na aonar,” arsa Dougie.
s.en: “And he is staying there by himself,” said Dougie.

s.gd: Tha Dougie fhéin pòsd ach chan eil mi smaoineachadh gu bheil am pòsadh uabhasach dòigheil oir bidh e dol suas am baile glé thric air a’ bhus (oir chan eil carbad aige) ’s thig e dhachaidh glé thric leis an daorach.
s.en: Dougie is himself married and I don’t think that the marriage is terribly happy because he goes up the town very often on the bus (because he doesn’t have a car) and he comes home very often drunk.

s.gd: Bha e anns an Eadailt anns a’ chogadh ’s bidh e bruidhinn glé thric air na Fascists ’s air tancaichean ’s nithean mar sin.
s.en: He was in Italy in the war and he talks very often about the Fascists and about tanks and things like that.

s.gd: Co-dhiùbh cha do chòrd an t-aonaran ris oir tha e fhéin glé fhaisg is càirdeil ’na dhòighean.
s.en: Anyway he didn’t like the loner because he himself is very close and friendly in his ways.

s.gd: “Cha robh gnothach aige thighinn an seo idir,” ars esan le feirg.
s.en: “He had no business coming here at all,” he said with anger.

s.gd: “Aonaran.
s.en: “A loner.

s.gd: Carson nach eil e pòsd mar a tha sinn uile?”
s.en: Why isn’t he married like we all are?”

s.gd: (Chan e ’n fhìrinn a th’aig an seo oir tha grunn ghillean air a’ bhaile nach eil pòsd.)
s.en: (He doesn’t have this right because there are a few lads in the town who are not married.)

s.gd: “Co-dhiùbh, cha dubhairt mise smid,” ars esan a rithist.
s.en: “Anyway, I didn’t say anything,” he said again.

s.gd: “Cha do leig mi càil orm.”
s.en: “I didn’t lay a thing on me.”

s.gd: “Tigh na galla,” arsa Dougie, “mur a h-eil e airson bruidhinn thoireadh e ’n t-sitig air.
s.en: “Sod him,” said Dougie, “if he doesn’t want to speak then let him go to hell.

s.gd: Ach co-dhiùbh,” ars esan le gàire a rithist, “ma tha ’n t-airgead aige, gheibh e a threalaichean ged a b’e Ruiseanach a bhiodh ann.”
s.en: But anyway,” he said again with a smile, “if he has the money, he will get his bits and pieces even if he were a Russian.”

s.gd: ’S cha robh càil a dh’fhios aig Dougie nach e Ruiseanach a bh’ann.
s.en: And Dougie didn’t know that he wasn’t a Russian.

s.gd: No aig duin’ eile.
s.en: Nor did anyone else.
